Award.AwardTitle: Strengthening the STEM Pipeline for Elementary School African Americans, Hispanics, and Girls by Scaling Up Summer Engineering Experiences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a collaborative proposal among the National Society of Black Engineers (NSBE), Virginia Tech, and Purdue University, submitted to the Successful Project Expansion and Dissemination strand of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program. It aims to expand the implementation of a NSBE-supported program, "Summer Engineering Experiences for Kids", from 14 sites in 2016, to 31 by 2019; from 3,825 3rd-5th grade African American, Hispanic, and female students in 2015, to cumulatively 27,000 across the nation over the three-year duration of the project. By 2019, a total of 42,000 students will have been impacted by the program since its inception in 2007. The project will advance efforts of the ITEST program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in the fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by engaging them in a summer program through hands-on, team-based engineering design projects led by collegiate mentor-teachers. The project will use "A World in Motion"--an engineering curriculum for elementary and middle school children developed by the Society of Automotive Engineers, in addition to other STEM curricula to be incorporated across sites. Participants will experience applied engineering and computer programming learning opportunities, including engineering principles and related mathematics and science concepts and practices through selected activities. While expanding the program, researchers in the partnership will investigate the contextual factors that facilitate or constrain its implementation in order to develop a prototype with a potential to be used in various learning environments. Thus, the overall hypothesis of the work will be that organizational contexts enable, inhibit, and shape the experiences that students have, and consequently influence their outcomes.

The three research questions will be: (1) For each site and across all sites, what is the change in students' STEM-related academic and career identity, conceptual knowledge, and interpersonal and intrapersonal skills?; (2) What is the relationship between students' academic motivation (i.e., empowerment, usefulness, success, interest, caring) and their STEM-related academic and career identity, conceptual knowledge, and interpersonal and intrapersonal skills?; and (3) How do organizational context factors influence students' experiences and outcomes? To address the first question, outcome measures will be administered in a pretest-posttest format to identify changes in students' STEM-related outcomes over the course of the program. To address the second research question, the project will use multilevel modeling to incorporate site-specific contextual variables. To address the third research question, the project will employ a multi-case study approach to investigate variation in available resources and implementation strategies across sites each year. Through multiple data collection methods, the research will capture the influential contextual factors of different sites and their relationship with students' experiences and outcomes. An advisory panel comprising scholars and practitioners in engineering education, engineering outreach programs, and research will provide oversight of the project's progress and an independent mechanism for evaluation. An external evaluator will conduct both formative and summative aspects of the project. The key outcome of the effort will be a research-informed and field-tested model to increase African American, Hispanic, and female students' achievement and engagement in STEM disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative project between the National Society of Black Engineers (NSBE), Virginia Tech, and Purdue University focused on enhancing, expanding, and studying the implementation of NSBE's Summer Engineering Experiences for Kids (SEEK) program. 

SEEK is a three-week long out-of-school program geared toward upper-elementary-aged children in low-income communities. Each week-long curriculum module focused on a different engineering challenge that culminated in a competition day where teams demonstrated their learning and project work in front of family members, friends, engineers, and industry sponsors. This suite of activities, combined with interactions with Black and Latinx college-aged mentors and teachers who staff the camps as well as industry sponsors, worked toward broadening children's perceptions of engineering as a field and career path.

 

SEEK helps children see themselves as future engineers and develop skills and competencies that are associated with the engineering profession. It provided an engineering-focused experience that enabled children to experience the engineering design process, build their math, science, and critical thinking skills, and engage in team-based environments. Intentionally aiming to reach underserved communities with high populations of Black children (and in certain cities, both Black and Latinx children), NSBE hosted SEEK in over a dozen cities in each year of the project. Over the course of the project, more than 4,800 children participated in SEEK--over 90% of those children identified as Black or African American.

 

The project enhanced educational activities within each site. New curricular modules focusing on emerging technologies were implemented; existing curricula were updated to help children better recognize the connection between engineering and improving the human condition; the design process was threaded through modules for a consist, research-informed framework for thinking through engineering problems; examples of African American engineers were brought into learning spaces across sites; and new resources to support engineering learning at home were shared with families. The work from this project led to the development of resources and support for classroom teachers and classroom experiences.

 

The project also supported the development of human resources. The partnerships between NSBE and two research universities led to new learning opportunities for all project personnel, including providing opportunities to learn how to conduct research in informal secondary school learning environments for 14 doctoral students and two postdocs. Mentors and site leaders who staff SEEK are essential for the camp's success, serving as role models for participating children. Over the course of the project, over 50 site leaders and 400 mentors served in these roles and had opportunities to develop new skills related to teaching and communicating engineering to children; the project developed modules for mentors that focused on inclusive engineering pedagogies. We also have substantial evidence that engaging in SEEK is a positive professional development opportunity for mentors, often leading to a greater interest in teaching and strong connections with industry sponsors through opportunities like summer internships.

 

This project also produced new research on understanding how informal learning environments can impact pre-college children. Over the three year project we built a comprehensive, multi-method data set consisting of quantitative measures of math, science, and engineering conceptual understanding, engineering identity, interests and perceptions of engineering, teamwork and communication skills, academic motivation and team processes, and interests in math and science; open-ended design process skills scenarios and draw an engineer tasks; questionnaires from parents, mentors, and site leaders; classroom observations; and interviews with NSBE personnel, mentors and site leaders, and children. We are unaware of such a comprehensive data set focused on an informal learning environment aimed at broadening participation in engineering for African American youth. Select findings from this research to date demonstrate the following:

  • SEEK is particularly effective at enhancing childrens' engineering identity and broadening their perceptions of what it means to be an engineer.
  • SEEK's comprehensive and systematic approach to situate its programming in specific cities and reduce barriers to participation has yielded participation that reflects its target population. Other outreach programs could learn from this comprehensive strategy.
  • Using SEEK as an instrumental case, we outlined the programmatic components that go into executing a large-scale community-based STEM outreach program for underserved communities. There is an advantage to adopting a collective impact mindset when scaling up outreach initiatives, and it is important to ground programmatic practices and changes in research to identify areas of success and areas of need.
  • A series of required tradeoffs must be carefully considered to offer and study an effective intervention (i.e., outreach program) designed to affirm a cultural background while simultaneously broadening access by offering the intervention at scale. Tensions that program leaders must grapple with include: 1) Including Dominant Narratives and Counter Narratives, 2) Managing Strategic Recruitment and Participation Management, and 3) Supporting a Shared Vision and Divergent Objectives.
